Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: They strictly follow a detailed schedule of daily prayers, chanting, and offerings, ensuring nothing is skipped.
Story: My younger sister had been looking forward to our family’s weekend picnic for weeks. She’d even asked me, “Promise you’ll come this time?” I could see how much it meant to her, and as her brother, I wanted to be there, to laugh with her and make her feel included. But the picnic was scheduled right in the middle of my daily puja time—a time I dedicate to prayers, chanting, and offerings, following the schedule my family has kept for generations. My parents expect me to uphold these rituals without fail, and I feel a deep responsibility to honor our traditions. As the day approached, I felt torn. My sister’s hopeful eyes haunted me, but so did the thought of breaking my spiritual routine. I kept replaying both expectations in my mind: being the supportive brother she needed, and the devoted Hindu I was raised to be. The pressure built inside me, and I found myself caught between two worlds, unable to see how I could possibly meet both demands.
